description: The Algolia API includes autocomplete functionality and an instant results display.

blocks.name: getLogs
blocks.description: Return last logs.

args.name: apiKey
args.info: Algolia Application Key.

args.name: appId
args.info: Algolia Application ID.

args.name: offset
args.info: Specify the first entry to retrieve (0-based, 0 is the most recent log entry). Defaults to 0.

args.name: length
args.info: Specify the maximum number of entries to retrieve starting at offset. Defaults to 10. Maximum allowed value: 1000.

args.name: type
args.info: Specify the type of logs to retrieve. This parameter is useful for debugging, especially when it is difficult to locate errors among many API calls:`all` (default): Retrieve all logs; `query`: Retrieve only the queries; `build`: Retrieve only the build operations; `error`: Retrieve only the errors

blocks.name: addGlobalApiKey
blocks.description: This method add a new global API key.

args.name: apiKey
args.info: Algolia Application Key.

args.name: appId
args.info: Algolia Application ID.

args.name: validity
args.info: Specify a validity for this key in seconds (the key will automatically be removed after this period of time). Defaults to 0 (no validity limit).

args.name: maxQueriesPerIPPerHour
args.info: Specify the maximum number of API calls allowed from an IP address per hour.

args.name: maxHitsPerQuery
args.info: Specify the maximum number of hits this API key can retrieve in one call. Defaults to 0 (unlimited).

args.name: acl
args.info: List of Strings. Contains the list of rights for this key. Here is the complete list of ACL that can be used for a key: `search`, `browse`, `addObject`, `deleteObject`, `deleteIndex`, `settings`, `editSettings`, `analytics`, `listIndexes`. See README for more info.

args.name: indexes
args.info: Restrict this new API key to specific index names. This option is useful if you want to isolate your development and production environments: you can have one API key targeting all development indices and another one that target all production indices. You can target all indices starting by a prefix or finishing by a suffix with the ‘*’ character (for example “dev_*” matches all indices starting by “dev_” and “*_dev” matches all indices finishing by “_dev”). If the list is empty or not set, the API Key will be valid for all indices.

args.name: referers
args.info: Restrict this new API key to specific referers. You can specify a pattern with one or two *. For example, “https://algolia.com/*” matches all referers starting with “https://algolia.com/” and “*algolia.com” matches all referers ending with “.algolia.com”. You can combine both of them to like “*.algolia.com*” to allow the domain algolia.com. Defaults to all referers if empty or blank

args.name: queryParameters
args.info: Force some query parameters to be applied foreach query made with this api key. You can force all query parameters like: “typoTolerance=strict&ignorePlurals=false&filters=rights:public”. The parameters use the url string format.

args.name: description
args.info: Used to identify a key.

blocks.name: updateGlobalApiKey
blocks.description: This method update a global API key.

args.name: apiKey
args.info: Algolia Application Key.

args.name: appId
args.info: Algolia Application ID.

args.name: key
args.info: Key to update

args.name: validity
args.info: Specify a validity for this key in seconds (the key will automatically be removed after this period of time). Defaults to 0 (no validity limit).

args.name: maxQueriesPerIPPerHour
args.info: Specify the maximum number of API calls allowed from an IP address per hour.

args.name: maxHitsPerQuery
args.info: Specify the maximum number of hits this API key can retrieve in one call. Defaults to 0 (unlimited).

args.name: acl
args.info: List of Strings. Contains the list of rights for this key. Here is the complete list of ACL that can be used for a key: `search`, `browse`, `addObject`, `deleteObject`, `deleteIndex`, `settings`, `editSettings`, `analytics`, `listIndexes`. See README for more info.

args.name: indexes
args.info: Restrict this new API key to specific index names. This option is useful if you want to isolate your development and production environments: you can have one API key targeting all development indices and another one that target all production indices. You can target all indices starting by a prefix or finishing by a suffix with the ‘*’ character (for example “dev_*” matches all indices starting by “dev_” and “*_dev” matches all indices finishing by “_dev”). If the list is empty or not set, the API Key will be valid for all indices.

args.name: referers
args.info: Restrict this new API key to specific referers. You can specify a pattern with one or two *. For example, “https://algolia.com/*” matches all referers starting with “https://algolia.com/” and “*algolia.com” matches all referers ending with “.algolia.com”. You can combine both of them to like “*.algolia.com*” to allow the domain algolia.com. Defaults to all referers if empty or blank

args.name: queryParameters
args.info: Force some query parameters to be applied foreach query made with this api key. You can force all query parameters like: “typoTolerance=strict&ignorePlurals=false&filters=rights:public”. The parameters use the url string format.

args.name: description
args.info: Used to identify a key.

args.name: apiKey
args.info: Algolia Application Key.

args.name: appId
args.info: Algolia Application ID.

args.name: key

args.name: key

blocks.name: searchSynonyms
blocks.description: Search/browse all synonyms, possibly filtered by type

args.name: apiKey
args.info: Algolia Application Key.

args.name: appId
args.info: Algolia Application ID.

args.name: indexName
args.info: Index name to search synonyms for

args.name: query
args.info: The query string used to search for specific synonyms. Use an empty string (default) to browse all synonyms.

args.name: type
args.info: Only search within specific types of synonyms. Multiple types can be specified using a comma-separated list. Possible values: `synonym`, `onewaysynonym`, `altcorrection1`, `altcorrection2`, `placeholder`

args.name: page
args.info: The page to fetch (first page is 0).

args.name: hitsPerPage
args.info: The number of synonyms to fetch per page.

args.name: indexName
args.info: Index name.

args.name: objectId
args.info: Object ID.

args.name: forwardToSlave
args.info: Push the new/updated synonyms set to all slave indices

args.name: synonyms
args.info: List of synonym strings

blocks.name: updateRegularSynonymSet
blocks.description: Update a new regular synonym set

args.name: apiKey
args.info: Algolia Application Key.

args.name: appId
args.info: Algolia Application ID.

args.name: indexName
args.info: Index name.

args.name: objectId

args.name: forwardToSlave
args.info: Push the new/updated synonyms set to all slave indices

args.name: synonyms
args.info: List of synonym strings

blocks.name: createOneWaySynonymSet
blocks.description: Create a new one-way synonym set

args.name: apiKey
args.info: Algolia Application Key.

args.name: appId
args.info: Algolia Application ID.

args.name: indexName
args.info: Index name.

args.name: objectId
args.info: Object ID.

args.name: forwardToSlave
args.info: Push the new/updated synonyms set to all slave indices

args.name: input
args.info: Let’s take an example. When a user searches for “tablet”, you want them to be able to find iPads and Galaxy Note tablets alike, but you might not want Android tablets to show up when they search for “iPad”. To do this, you would create a one-way synonym record between tablet (as input) and ipad, galaxy note (as synonyms). When the user types in “tablet”, records containing “iPad” and “Galaxy Note” will be returned. However records containing only “tablet” or “Galaxy Note” won’t be returned if he searches for “iPad”.

args.name: synonyms
args.info: List of synonym strings

blocks.description: Update a new one-way synonym set

args.name: indexName

args.name: objectId

args.name: forwardToSlave
args.info: Push the new/updated synonyms set to all slave indices

args.name: input
args.info: Let’s take an example. When a user searches for “tablet”, you want them to be able to find iPads and Galaxy Note tablets alike, but you might not want Android tablets to show up when they search for “iPad”. To do this, you would create a one-way synonym record between tablet (as input) and ipad, galaxy note (as synonyms). When the user types in “tablet”, records containing “iPad” and “Galaxy Note” will be returned. However records containing only “tablet” or “Galaxy Note” won’t be returned if he searches for “iPad”.

args.name: synonyms
args.info: List of synonym strings

blocks.name: getIndexes
blocks.description: This command lists all your existing indexes.

args.name: apiKey
args.info: Algolia Application Key.

args.name: appId
args.info: Algolia Application ID.

blocks.name: querySingleIndex
blocks.description: Return objects that match the query. See README.

args.name: apiKey
args.info: Algolia Application Key.

args.name: appId
args.info: Algolia Application ID.

args.name: indexName
args.info: Inex name to retrieve.

args.name: query
args.info: The instant-search query string, all words of the query are interpreted as prefixes (for example “John Mc” will match “John Mccamey” and “Johnathan Mccamey”). If no query parameter is set, retrieves all objects.

args.name: queryType
args.info: Selects how the query words are interpreted: `prefixAll`, `prefixLast`, `prefixNone`

args.name: typoTolerance
args.info: This setting has four different options: `true` (default), `false`, `min`: keep only results with the lowest number of typo, `strict`: if there is a match without typo, then all results with 2 typos or more will be removed.

args.name: minWordSizefor1Typo
args.info: The minimum number of characters in a query word to accept one typo in this word. Defaults to 4.

args.name: minWordSizefor2Typos
args.info: The minimum number of characters in a query word to accept two typos in this word. Defaults to 8.

args.name: allowTyposOnNumericTokens
args.info: If set to false, disable typo-tolerance on numeric tokens (=numbers) in the query word. For example the query `304` will match with `30450`, but not with `40450` that would have been the case with typo-tolerance enabled. Can be very useful on serial numbers and zip codes searches. Defaults to true.

args.name: ignorePlurals
args.info: If set to true, simple plural forms won’t be considered as typos (for example car/cars will be considered as equal). Defaults to false.

args.name: restrictSearchableAttributes
args.info: List of attributes you want to use for textual search

args.name: advancedSyntax
args.info: Enable the advanced query syntax. Defaults to 0 (false).

args.name: analytics
args.info: If set to false, this query will not be taken into account for the Analytics. Defaults to true.

args.name: analyticsTags
args.info: Comma-separated string list. If set, tag your query with the specified identifiers. Tags can then be used in the Analytics to analyze a subset of searches only.

args.name: synonyms
args.info: If set to false, this query will not use synonyms defined in configuration. Defaults to true.

args.name: replaceSynonymsInHighlight
args.info: If set to false, words matched via synonyms expansion will not be replaced by the matched synonym in the highlighted result. Defaults to true.

args.name: optionalWords
args.info: List of Strings. Specify a list of words that should be considered as optional when found in the query

structure.name: word
structure.info: Word that should be considered as optional when found in the query

args.name: minProximity
args.info: Configure the precision of the proximity ranking criterion. See README for more info.

args.name: removeWordsIfNoResults
args.info: Configure the way query words are removed when the query doesn’t retrieve any results. See README for more info.

args.name: disableTypoToleranceOnAttributes
args.info: List of attributes on which you want to disable typo tolerance

args.name: removeStopWords
args.info: Boolean or comma-separated string list. See README for more info

args.name: exactOnSingleWordQuery
args.info: This parameter control how the exact ranking criterion is computed when the query contains one word. There is three different values: `none`, `word`, `attribute`.

args.name: alternativesAsExact
args.info: Specify the list of approximation that should be considered as an exact match in the ranking formula. See README for more info.

structure.name: alternative
structure.info: Approximation that should be considered as an exact match in the ranking formula.

args.name: page
args.info: Pagination parameter used to select the page to retrieve. Page is zero-based and defaults to 0. Thus, to retrieve the 10th page you need to set page=9

args.name: hitsPerPage
args.info: Pagination parameter used to select the number of hits per page. Defaults to 20.

args.name: offset
args.info: Instead of page/hitsPerPage, you can use offset/length to specify the number of hits you want to retrieve and from which offset you want to start.

args.name: length
args.info: Instead of page/hitsPerPage, you can use offset/length to specify the number of hits you want to retrieve and from which offset you want to start.

args.name: attributesToRetrieve
args.info: List of object attributes you want to retrieve (let you minimize the answer size). See README for more info.

args.name: attributesToHighlight
args.info: List of attributes you want to highlight according to the query. Attributes are separated by a comma. See README for more info.

args.name: attributesToSnippet
args.info: List of attributes to snippet alongside the number of words to return. See README for more info.

args.name: getRankingInfo
args.info: If set to 1, the result hits will contain ranking information in _rankingInfo attribute.

args.name: highlightPreTag
args.info: Specify the string that is inserted before the highlighted parts in the query result (defaults to `<em>`).

args.name: highlightPostTag
args.info: Specify the string that is inserted after the highlighted parts in the query result (defaults to ``

args.name: snippetEllipsisText
args.info: String used as an ellipsis indicator when a snippet is truncated (defaults to empty).

args.name: responseFields
args.info: Comma-separated string list. See README for more info.

args.name: numericFilters
args.info: The list of numeric filters you want to apply separated by a comma. See README for more info.

args.name: tagFilters
args.info: Filter the query by a set of tags. You can AND tags by separating them by commas. See README for more info.

args.name: distinct
args.info: Enable the distinct feature (disabled by default) if the attributeForDistinct index setting is set. This feature is similar to the SQL “distinct” keyword: when enabled in a query with the distinct=1 parameter, all hits containing a duplicate value for theattributeForDistinct attribute are removed from results. For example, if the chosen attribute is show_name and several hits have the same value for show_name, then only the best one is kept and others are removed.

args.name: facets
args.info: List of object attributes that you want to use for faceting. Attributes are separated with a comma. See README for more info.

args.name: facetFilters
args.info: Filter the query by a list of facets. Facets are separated by commas and each facet is encoded as attributeName:value. See README for more info.

args.name: maxValuesPerFacet
args.info: Limit the number of facet values returned for each facet. For example: maxValuesPerFacet=10 will retrieve max 10 values per facet. Defaults to 100.

args.name: filters
args.info: Filter the query with numeric, facet or/and tag filters. The syntax is a SQL like syntax, you can use the OR and AND keywords. See README for more info.

args.name: aroundLatLng
args.info: Search for entries around a given latitude/longitude (specified as two floats separated by a comma. See README for more info.

args.name: aroundRadius
args.info: Control the radius associated with a aroundLatLng or aroundLatLngViaIP query.

args.name: aroundPrecision
args.info: Control the precision of a aroundLatLng query. In meter. For example if you set aroundPrecision=100, two objects that are in the range 0-99m will be considered as identical in the ranking for the .variable geo ranking parameter (same for 100-199, 200-299, … ranges).

args.name: minimumAroundRadius
args.info: Define the minimum radius used for aroundLatLng or aroundLatLngViaIP when aroundRadius is not set. The radius is computed automatically using the density of the area. You can retrieve the computed radius in the automaticRadius attribute of the answer.

args.name: insideBoundingBox
args.info: Search for entries inside a given area defined by the two extreme points of a rectangle. See README for more info.

args.name: insidePolygon
args.info: Search entries inside a given area defined by a set of points (defined by a minimum of 6 floats. See README for more info.

blocks.name: deleteSingleIndex
blocks.description: This method deletes an existing index.

args.name: apiKey
args.info: Algolia Application Key.

args.name: appId

args.name: indexName

args.name: indexName
args.info: Index name to clear

args.name: object
args.info: Object body. See README for more info.

blocks.name: updateSingleObject
blocks.description: This method adds or replaces an object (if the object does not exist, it will be created). Be careful, when an object already exists for the specified object ID, the whole object is replaced: existing attributes that are not replaced are deleted.

args.name: apiKey
args.info: Algolia Application Key.

args.name: appId
args.info: Algolia Application ID.

args.name: indexName
args.info: Index name to add object for.

args.name: objectId
args.info: Index name to add object for.

args.name: object
args.info: Object body. See README for more info.

blocks.name: partiallyUpdateObject
blocks.description: This method updates part of an object (if the object does not exist, it will be created. You can avoid an automatic creation of the object by passing createIfNotExists=false as query argument).

args.name: apiKey
args.info: Algolia Application Key.

args.name: appId
args.info: Algolia Application ID.

args.name: indexName
args.info: Index name to add object for.

args.name: objectId
args.info: Index name to add object for.

args.name: object
args.info: Object body. See README for more info.

args.name: createIfNotExists
args.info: You can avoid an automatic creation of the object. Defaults is `true`

blocks.name: getSingleObject
blocks.description: This method returns one object from the index.

args.name: apiKey
args.info: Algolia Application Key.

args.name: appId
args.info: Algolia Application ID.

args.name: indexName
args.info: Index name to add object for.

args.name: objectId
args.info: Index name to add object for.

blocks.name: getObjects
blocks.description: This method allows to retrieve several objects with one API call.

args.name: apiKey
args.info: Algolia Application Key.

args.name: appId
args.info: Algolia Application ID.

args.name: requests
args.info: JSON Array of Objects. See README for more info.

blocks.name: deleteSingleObject
blocks.description: This method deletes an existing object from the index

args.name: apiKey
args.info: Algolia Application Key.

args.name: appId
args.info: Algolia Application ID.

args.name: indexName
args.info: Index name to delete.

args.name: objectId
args.info: Index name to delete.

blocks.name: getIndexSettings
blocks.description: This method retrieve index settings.

args.name: apiKey
args.info: Algolia Application Key.

args.name: appId
args.info: Algolia Application ID.

args.name: indexName
args.info: Index name to retrieve settings for.

args.name: attributesToIndex
args.info: List of Strings. The list of fields you want to index. If set to null, all textual attributes of your objects are indexed, but you should update it to get optimal results. See README for more info.

args.name: numericAttributesToIndex
args.info: All numerical attributes are automatically indexed as numerical filters. If you don’t need filtering on some of your numerical attributes, please consider sending them as strings to speed up the indexing. If you only need to filter on a numeric value with the operator = or !=, you can speed up the indexing by specifying the attribute with equalOnly(AttributeName). The other operators will be disabled.

args.name: attributesForFaceting
args.info: The list of fields you want to use for faceting. All strings in the attribute selected for faceting are extracted and added as a facet. By default, no attribute is used for faceting.

args.name: attributeForDistinct
args.info: The attribute name used for the Distinct feature. This feature is similar to the SQL “distinct” keyword: when enabled in query with the distinct=1 parameter, all hits containing a duplicate value for this attribute are removed from results. For example, if the chosen attribute is show_name and several hits have the same value for show_name, then only the best one is kept and others are removed.

args.name: ranking
args.info: Link of Strings. Controls the way results are sorted. See README for more info.

structure.name: control
structure.info: Control the way results are sorted.

args.name: customRanking
args.info: List of Strings. Lets you specify part of the ranking. The syntax of this condition is an array of strings containing attributes prefixed by asc (ascending order) or desc (descending order) operator. For example: `customRanking`: [`desc(population)`, `asc(name)`]

args.name: separatorsToIndex
args.info: Specify the separators (punctuation characters) to index. By default, separators are not indexed. Use `+#` to be able to search Google+ or C#.

args.name: slaves
args.info: JSON Array of String. The list of indexes on which you want to replicate all write operations. In order to get response times in milliseconds, we pre-compute part of the ranking during indexing. If you want to use different ranking configurations depending of the use-case, you need to create one index per ranking configuration. This option enables you to perform write operations only on this index, and to automatically update slave indexes with the same operations.

args.name: unretrievableAttributes
args.info: JSON Array Of Strings. List of attributes that cannot be retrieved at query time. This feature allows you to have an attribute that is used for indexing and/or ranking but which cannot be retrieved. This setting will be bypassed if the query is done with the ADMIN API key. Defaults to null.

args.name: allowCompressionOfIntegerArray
args.info: Allows compression of big integer arrays. We recommended to store the list of user ID or rights as an integer array and enable this setting. When enabled the integer array are reordered to reach a better compression ratio. Defaults to false.

args.name: synonyms
args.info: List of synonym strings

args.name: placeholders
args.info: JSON Hash. This is an advanced use case to define a token substitutable by a list of words without having the original token searchable. See README for more info.

args.name: altCorrections
args.info: Specify alternative corrections that you want to consider. See README for more info.

args.name: disableTypoToleranceOnWords
args.info: List of String. Specify a list of words on which the automatic typo tolerance will be disabled.

structure.name: word
structure.info: Word on which the automatic typo tolerance will be disabled

args.name: disableTypoToleranceOnAttributes
args.info: JSON Array of Strings. List of attributes on which you want to disable typo tolerance (must be a subset of the attributesToIndex index setting). By default the list is empty.

args.name: disablePrefixOnAttributes
args.info: JSON Array of Strings. List of attributes on which you want to disable typo tolerance (must be a subset of the attributesToIndex index setting). By default the list is empty.

args.name: disableExactOnAttributes
args.info: JSON Array of String. List of attributes on which you want to disable the computation of “exact” criteria (must be a subset of the attributesToIndex index setting). By default the list is empty.

args.name: minWordSizefor1Typo
args.info: The minimum number of characters to accept one typo (default = 4).

args.name: minWordSizefor2Typos
args.info: The minimum number of characters to accept two typos (default = 8).

args.name: hitsPerPage
args.info: The number of hits per page (default = 10).

args.name: attributesToRetrieve
args.info: JSON Array of String. Default list of attributes to retrieve in objects. If set to null, all attributes are retrieved.

args.name: attributesToHighlight
args.info: JSON Array of String. Default list of attributes to highlight. If set to null, all indexed attributes are highlighted.

args.name: attributesToSnippet
args.info: JSON Array of Strings. Default list of attributes to snippet alongside the number of words to return (syntax is ‘attributeName:nbWords’). If set to null, no snippet is computed.

args.name: queryType
args.info: Select how the query words are interpreted, it can be one of the following value: `prefixAll`, `prefixLast`, `prefixNone`.

args.name: minProximity
args.info: Configure the precision of the proximity ranking criterion. See README for more info.

args.name: highlightPreTag
args.info: Specify the string that is inserted before the highlighted parts in the query result (defaults to `<em>`).

args.name: highlightPostTag
args.info: Specify the string that is inserted after the highlighted parts in the query result (defaults to `</em>`).

args.name: optionalWords
args.info: List of Strings. Specify a list of words that should be considered as optional when found in the query

structure.name: word
structure.info: Word that should be considered as optional when found in the query

args.name: allowTyposOnNumericTokens
args.info: If set to false, disable typo-tolerance on numeric tokens (=numbers) in the query word. For example the query `304` will match with `30450`, but not with `40450` that would have been the case with typo-tolerance enabled. Can be very useful on serial numbers and zip codes searches. Defaults to false.

args.name: ignorePlurals
args.info: If set to true, simple plural forms won’t be considered as typos (for example car/cars will be considered as equal). Defaults to false.

args.name: advancedSyntax
args.info: Enable the advanced query syntax. Defaults to 0 (false). See README for more info.

args.name: replaceSynonymsInHighlight
args.info: If set to false, words matched via synonyms expansion will not be replaced by the matched synonym in the highlighted result. Defaults to true.

args.name: maxValuesPerFacet
args.info: Limit the number of facet values returned for each facet. For example: maxValuesPerFacet=10 will retrieve max 10 values per facet. Defaults to 100.

args.name: distinct
args.info: Enable the distinct feature (disabled by default) if the attributeForDistinct index setting is set. This feature is similar to the SQL “distinct” keyword: when enabled in a query with the distinct=1 parameter, all hits containing a duplicate value for theattributeForDistinct attribute are removed from results. For example, if the chosen attribute is show_name and several hits have the same value for show_name, then only the best one is kept and others are removed.

args.name: typoTolerance
args.info: This setting has four different options: `true`, `false`, `min`, `strict`.

args.name: removeStopWords
args.info: Remove stop words from query before executing it. It can be a boolean: enable or disable all 41 supported languages or a string array with the list of languages you have in your record (using language iso code). See README for more info.

args.name: snippetEllipsisText
args.info: String used as an ellipsis indicator when a snippet is truncated. Default: `…` (U+2026 HORIZONTAL ELLIPSIS).

args.name: exactOnSingleWordQuery
args.info: This parameter control how the exact ranking criterion is computed when the query contains one word. There is three different values: `none`, `word`, `attribute`.

args.name: alternativesAsExact
args.info: Specify the list of approximation that should be considered as an exact match in the ranking formula. See README for more info.

structure.name: alternative
structure.info: Approximation that should be considered as an exact match in the ranking formula.

blocks.name: getIndexContent
blocks.description: This method allows you to retrieve all index content (for backup, SEO or analytics purpose). It can retrieve up to 1,000 records per call and supports full text search and filters.

args.name: apiKey
args.info: Algolia Application Key.

args.name: appId
args.info: Algolia Application ID.

args.name: indexName
args.info: Index name to retrieve content for.

blocks.name: changeIndexSettings
blocks.description: This method updates part of index settings, the list of attributes and their behavior are listed in the get index settings API.

args.name: apiKey
args.info: Algolia Application Key.

args.name: appId
args.info: Algolia Application ID.

args.name: indexName
args.info: Index name to retrieve settings for.

args.name: forwardToSlaves
args.info: If this parameter is true, the change is also applied on slaves of this index.

args.name: attributesToIndex
args.info: List of Strings. The list of fields you want to index. If set to null, all textual attributes of your objects are indexed, but you should update it to get optimal results. See README for more info.

args.name: numericAttributesToIndex
args.info: All numerical attributes are automatically indexed as numerical filters. If you don’t need filtering on some of your numerical attributes, please consider sending them as strings to speed up the indexing. If you only need to filter on a numeric value with the operator = or !=, you can speed up the indexing by specifying the attribute with equalOnly(AttributeName). The other operators will be disabled.

args.name: attributesForFaceting
args.info: The list of fields you want to use for faceting. All strings in the attribute selected for faceting are extracted and added as a facet. By default, no attribute is used for faceting.

args.name: attributeForDistinct
args.info: The attribute name used for the Distinct feature. This feature is similar to the SQL “distinct” keyword: when enabled in query with the distinct=1 parameter, all hits containing a duplicate value for this attribute are removed from results. For example, if the chosen attribute is show_name and several hits have the same value for show_name, then only the best one is kept and others are removed.

args.name: ranking
args.info: Link of Strings. Controls the way results are sorted. See README for more info.

structure.name: control
structure.info: Control the way results are sorted.

args.name: customRanking
args.info: List of Strings. Lets you specify part of the ranking. The syntax of this condition is an array of strings containing attributes prefixed by asc (ascending order) or desc (descending order) operator. For example: `customRanking`: [`desc(population)`, `asc(name)`]

args.name: separatorsToIndex
args.info: Specify the separators (punctuation characters) to index. By default, separators are not indexed. Use `+#` to be able to search Google+ or C#.

args.name: slaves
args.info: JSON Array of String. The list of indexes on which you want to replicate all write operations. In order to get response times in milliseconds, we pre-compute part of the ranking during indexing. If you want to use different ranking configurations depending of the use-case, you need to create one index per ranking configuration. This option enables you to perform write operations only on this index, and to automatically update slave indexes with the same operations.

args.name: unretrievableAttributes
args.info: JSON Array Of Strings. List of attributes that cannot be retrieved at query time. This feature allows you to have an attribute that is used for indexing and/or ranking but which cannot be retrieved. This setting will be bypassed if the query is done with the ADMIN API key. Defaults to null.

args.name: allowCompressionOfIntegerArray
args.info: Allows compression of big integer arrays. We recommended to store the list of user ID or rights as an integer array and enable this setting. When enabled the integer array are reordered to reach a better compression ratio. Defaults to false.

args.name: synonyms
args.info: List of synonym strings

args.name: placeholders
args.info: JSON Hash. This is an advanced use case to define a token substitutable by a list of words without having the original token searchable. See README for more info.

args.name: altCorrections
args.info: Specify alternative corrections that you want to consider. See README for more info.

args.name: disableTypoToleranceOnWords
args.info: List of String. Specify a list of words on which the automatic typo tolerance will be disabled.

structure.name: word
structure.info: Word on which the automatic typo tolerance will be disabled

args.name: disableTypoToleranceOnAttributes
args.info: JSON Array of Strings. List of attributes on which you want to disable typo tolerance (must be a subset of the attributesToIndex index setting). By default the list is empty.

args.name: disablePrefixOnAttributes
args.info: JSON Array of Strings. List of attributes on which you want to disable typo tolerance (must be a subset of the attributesToIndex index setting). By default the list is empty.

args.name: disableExactOnAttributes
args.info: JSON Array of String. List of attributes on which you want to disable the computation of “exact” criteria (must be a subset of the attributesToIndex index setting). By default the list is empty.

args.name: minWordSizefor1Typo
args.info: The minimum number of characters to accept one typo (default = 4).

args.name: minWordSizefor2Typos
args.info: The minimum number of characters to accept two typos (default = 8).

args.name: hitsPerPage
args.info: The number of hits per page (default = 10).

args.name: attributesToRetrieve
args.info: JSON Array of String. Default list of attributes to retrieve in objects. If set to null, all attributes are retrieved.

args.name: attributesToHighlight
args.info: JSON Array of String. Default list of attributes to highlight. If set to null, all indexed attributes are highlighted.

args.name: attributesToSnippet
args.info: JSON Array of Strings. Default list of attributes to snippet alongside the number of words to return (syntax is ‘attributeName:nbWords’). If set to null, no snippet is computed.

args.name: queryType
args.info: Select how the query words are interpreted, it can be one of the following value: `prefixAll`, `prefixLast`, `prefixNone`.

args.name: minProximity
args.info: Configure the precision of the proximity ranking criterion. See README for more info.

args.name: highlightPreTag
args.info: Specify the string that is inserted before the highlighted parts in the query result (defaults to `<em>`).

args.name: highlightPostTag
args.info: Specify the string that is inserted after the highlighted parts in the query result (defaults to `</em>`).

args.name: optionalWords
args.info: List of Strings. Specify a list of words that should be considered as optional when found in the query

structure.name: word
structure.info: Word that should be considered as optional when found in the query

args.name: allowTyposOnNumericTokens

Defaults to false.

For example, if the chosen attribute is show_name and several hits have the same value for show_name, then only the best one is kept and others are removed.

args.name: removeStopWords

blocks.name: copySingleIndex
blocks.description: This method copy an existing index. If the destination index already exists, its specific API keys will be preserved and the source index specific API keys will be added.

args.name: apiKey
args.info: Algolia Application Key.

args.name: appId
args.info: Algolia Application ID.

args.name: indexName
args.info: Index name to move

args.name: destination
args.info: Specify the name of the destination index

blocks.name: moveSingleIndex
blocks.description: This method move an existing index. If the destination index already exists, its specific API keys will be preserved and the source index specific API keys will be added.

args.name: apiKey
args.info: Algolia Application Key.

args.name: appId
args.info: Algolia Application ID.

args.name: indexName
args.info: Index name to move

args.name: destination
args.info: Specify the name of the destination index

blocks.name: getTaskStatus
blocks.description: This method gets the status of a given task (published or notPublished). Returns also a pendingTask flag that indicates if the index has remaining task(s) running.

args.name: apiKey
args.info: Algolia Application Key.

args.name: appId
args.info: Algolia Application ID.

args.name: indexName
args.info: Index name.

args.name: task
args.info: Task to retrieve status for.

blocks.name: addIndexSpecificApiKey
blocks.description: This method add a new key that can access to this index.

args.name: apiKey
args.info: Algolia Application Key.

args.name: appId
args.info: Algolia Application ID.

args.name: indexName
args.info: Used to identify a key.

args.name: description
args.info: Used to identify a key.

args.name: acl
args.info: List of Strings. Contains the list of rights for this key. Here is the complete list of ACL that can be used for a key: `search`, `browse`, `addObject`, `deleteObject`, `deleteIndex`, `settings`, `editSettings`, `analytics`, `listIndexes`. See README for more info.

args.name: referers
args.info: Restrict this new API key to specific referers. You can specify a pattern with one or two *. For example, “https://algolia.com/*” matches all referers starting with “https://algolia.com/” and “*algolia.com” matches all referers ending with “.algolia.com”. You can combine both of them to like “*.algolia.com*” to allow the domain algolia.com. Defaults to all referers if empty or blank

args.name: queryParameters
args.info: Force some query parameters to be applied foreach query made with this api key. You can force all query parameters like: “typoTolerance=strict&ignorePlurals=false&filters=rights:public”. The parameters use the url string format.

args.name: validity
args.info: Specify a validity for this key in seconds (the key will automatically be removed after this period of time). Defaults to 0 (no validity limit).

args.name: maxHitsPerQuery
args.info: Specify the maximum number of hits this API key can retrieve in one call. Defaults to 0 (unlimited). This parameter can be used to protect you from attempts at retrieving your entire content by massively querying the index.

blocks.name: updateIndexSpecificApiKey
blocks.description: This method update a key that can access to this index.

args.name: apiKey
args.info: Algolia Application Key.

args.name: appId
args.info: Algolia Application ID.

args.name: key
args.info: Key to update

args.name: indexName
args.info: Used to identify a key.

args.name: description
args.info: Used to identify a key.

args.name: acl
args.info: List of Strings. Contains the list of rights for this key. Here is the complete list of ACL that can be used for a key: `search`, `browse`, `addObject`, `deleteObject`, `deleteIndex`, `settings`, `editSettings`, `analytics`, `listIndexes`. See README for more info.

args.name: referers
args.info: Restrict this new API key to specific referers. You can specify a pattern with one or two *. For example, “https://algolia.com/*” matches all referers starting with “https://algolia.com/” and “*algolia.com” matches all referers ending with “.algolia.com”. You can combine both of them to like “*.algolia.com*” to allow the domain algolia.com. Defaults to all referers if empty or blank

args.name: queryParameters
args.info: Force some query parameters to be applied foreach query made with this api key. You can force all query parameters like: “typoTolerance=strict&ignorePlurals=false&filters=rights:public”. The parameters use the url string format.

args.name: validity
args.info: Specify a validity for this key in seconds (the key will automatically be removed after this period of time). Defaults to 0 (no validity limit).

args.name: maxHitsPerQuery
args.info: Specify the maximum number of hits this API key can retrieve in one call. Defaults to 0 (unlimited). This parameter can be used to protect you from attempts at retrieving your entire content by massively querying the index.

blocks.name: getIndexSpecificApiKeys
blocks.description: This method Lists API keys that have access to this index with their rights. These keys have been created with the add index specific key API.

args.name: apiKey
args.info: Algolia Application Key.

args.name: appId
args.info: Algolia Application ID.

args.name: indexName
args.info: Index Name to list keys for.

blocks.name: getIndexApiKeysForAllIndexes
blocks.description: This method update a key that can access to this index.

args.name: apiKey
args.info: Algolia Application Key.

args.name: appId
args.info: Algolia Application ID.

blocks.name: getIndexSpecificApiKeyRights
blocks.description: This method returns the rights of a given index specific API key that has been created with the add index specific key API.

args.name: apiKey
args.info: Algolia Application Key.

args.name: appId
args.info: Algolia Application ID.

args.name: indexName
args.info: Index name.

args.name: key
args.info: Key to retrieve.

blocks.name: deleteIndexSpecificApiKey
blocks.description: This method delete an index specific API key that have been created with the add index specific key API.

args.name: apiKey
args.info: Algolia Application Key.

args.name: appId
args.info: Algolia Application ID.

args.name: indexName
args.info: Index name.

args.name: key
args.info: Key to delete.

blocks.name: searchFacetValues
blocks.description: This method searches for values of a given facet, optionally restricting the returned values to those contained in objects matching other search criteria.

args.name: apiKey
args.info: Algolia Application Key.

args.name: appId
args.info: Algolia Application ID.

args.name: indexName
args.info: Index Name

args.name: facetName
args.info: Facet Name

args.name: params
args.info: You must specify at least the facetQuery parameter, which contains the text that will be searched inside the facet’s values. You may also specify any number of other regular search parameters. They will apply to objects in the index. See README for more info.
